head.title: Leonardo Used No Mirror for His Mirror Script

hedline.hl1: Leonardo Used No Mirror for His Mirror Script

abstract.p: Letter by Susan C Box and Richard H Kessin holds they were surprised to read Christopher Murray's suggestion (letter, Oct 29) that Leonardo da Vinci used a mirror to write (S)

block.p: We were surprised to read Christopher Murray's suggestion (letter, Oct. 29) that Leonardo da Vinci used a mirror to write.

Now on display as part of an exhibition we helped to arrange, ''The Art of Anatomy,'' in the Augustus C. Long Health Sciences Library of Columbia University, is a volume of Kenneth D. Keele and Carlos Pedretti's ''Corpus of the Anatomical Studies of Leonardo da Vinci,'' which says: ''Leonardo was left-handed and followed the natural impulse of writing backwards in a mirror script. This may have made the reading of his notes difficult to an untrained eye, but it was certainly not intended to make it impossible.''
We were surprised to read Christopher Murray's suggestion (letter, Oct. 29) that Leonardo da Vinci used a mirror to write.

Now on display as part of an exhibition we helped to arrange, ''The Art of Anatomy,'' in the Augustus C. Long Health Sciences Library of Columbia University, is a volume of Kenneth D. Keele and Carlos Pedretti's ''Corpus of the Anatomical Studies of Leonardo da Vinci,'' which says: ''Leonardo was left-handed and followed the natural impulse of writing backwards in a mirror script. This may have made the reading of his notes difficult to an untrained eye, but it was certainly not intended to make it impossible.''

According to an early expert on this phenomenon, MacDonald Critchley, mirror-writing is a term that simply describes a script that ''runs in the opposite direction to the normal, the individual letters being also reversed. The writing is therefore illegible until held up before a looking glass.''
